text:
<@U02469XJPGW> We pay $0.12-0.15/word in most cases. $0.12 is reserved for writers *we* are training — like, without any SEO writing experience — and $0.15 is for the somewhat experienced folks. I freelanced for 5 years before starting my agency and I'm paying more than I made in almost every circumstance, and I had done some legwork to make sure I wasn't underpaying (or being underpaid, when freelancing).

My original question was because I got pitched $1/word from a freelance writer last week for content that should take 4-6 hours to produce. On the high end of an hourly range, that's $266/hour. It's not specialty content that should require that type of rate — particularly as it's not at all research-heavy. I can see that if you're talking about something that requires super niche experience or multiple days of research and writing to produce, but not a typical piece.

I know outlining and writing aren't the same, but I was once a freelance writer and had clients send me topics with a few bullet points and no actual outline. We write a super detailed outline. It's different than what I was given while making a great deal less per post. I included that in my post because of my previous experiences.

text: <@U01K0BWEQD6> Can I ask what type of content and research you're working on? That is so much more than my agency even charges for completed pieces (optimized and edited) but I can see that for pieces that require a ton of research and legwork. I'm just very curious!
